user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible:
```c
bool UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible(const UT_RetvalConfigEntry_t *Rvc, const char *WantTypeName, UT_ValueGenre_t WantGenre)
{
    bool IsCompatible;

    /* If the type names were specified on both sides, and they match, then the value is compatible */
    if (Rvc->TypeName != NULL && WantTypeName != NULL)
    {
        IsCompatible = (strcmp(Rvc->TypeName, WantTypeName) == 0);
    }
    else
    {
        /* The types are not _directly_ assignable, but it could possibly be coerced */
        IsCompatible = false;
    }

    /*
     * As an alternative/fallback, if the value genre is known for both sides,
     * check if coercion is a possibility.  For example, this could apply if the
     * value was int32 on one side and int16 on the other.
     */
    if (!IsCompatible && Rvc->Genre != UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE && Rvc->Genre == WantGenre)
    {
        /* Genre match - should be compatible, with a potential size adjustment */
        IsCompatible = true;
    }

    return IsCompatible;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the strcmp usage (and its guarding null-pointer check) touches string handling and therefore can potentially read beyond the referenced objects if the pointed buffers are not properly null-terminated or sized. No other lines in the function call any <string.h> functions (no memcpy/memset/strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/strlen/strspn/etc.), perform pointer arithmetic, or manipulate raw memory, so they do not fall under Rule 21.17 and need not be investigated for this specific rule. The genre comparisons and boolean logic are simple value checks and are not relevant to bounds accesses of string objects.
